headerText: Energy services are central to most aspects of life. The power sector country profiles provide a country-level view of the power sector, which represents a subset of the energy sector that is focused on electricity generation.

countrySelector.mainText: The power sector represents about 20% of final energy consumption and *[42% of energy greenhouse gas emissions](https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions?breakBy=sector&chartType=percentage&sectors=building%2Celectricity-heat%2Cfugitive-emissions%2Cmanufacturing-construction%2Cother-fuel-combustion%2Ctransportation)*. Power enables electricity access, but also causes climate change, air pollution, increases water use and faces risks to natural hazards. See a global overview below or select a country to explore  national power sectors.

sections.header: What is the relationship of the power and energy sector?
sections.description: The power sector is a small share of the energy sector (which  includes direct fossil fuel use by transport, industry and building). Most climate scenarios show that achieve the goals of the *[Paris Agreement](https://www.wri.org/climate/expert-perspective/paris-agreement-strategy-longer-term)* will require to *[optimize, electrify and decarbonize](https://www.wri.org/blog/2020/01/6-lessons-energy-decarbonization-countries-leading-way)* the energy sector. This means reducing total energy use through improved efficiency, shift energy demand from direct fossil fuel burining to electricity and ensure this electricity is zero carbon. The charts below show if efficiency is improving and if the energy sector is electrifying.

sections.header: How can power be affected by natural hazards?
sections.description: Societies rely on the critical electricity infrastructure, which is susceptible to natural hazards including floods, fires, earthquakes, and many others. To better understand those hazards and managed vulnerabilities you can overlay power supply and demand data with natural hazards below.
sections.title: Power sector assets and natural hazards that might impact them

sections.description: Changes in countries' power consumption can drive an increase or decrease in demand. An increase in demand can be met by generation based on fossil fuels (coal, oil, gas), nuclear, and renewables (hydro, wind, solar, biomass). The charts below show you how consumption is changing and how demand is met with renewable and non-renewable sources.

sections.header: Who is lacking access to electricity?
sections.description: Clean and convenient modern electricity is still out of reach for many, but the energy transition also provides many opportunities for action. The charts below how many people lack acess to electricity, and what potential there is for investment in new renewable power generation.

sections.header: Where can we expand wind and solar power?
sections.description: Compared to 2009, the global average costs of renewable have dropped by *[89% for solar, 70% for wind and 87% for battery storage by 2019](https://www.wri.org/publication/tracking-progress-2020-climate-turning-point)*, making it *[the cheapest power for 67% of the world](https://www.wri.org/blog/2020/05/setting-record-straight-about-renewable-energy)*. Use the maps to explore the potential of new wind and solar power generation.

sections.header: How much does power contribute to climate change and what are countries doing about it?
sections.description: The power sector is the *[single largest greenhouse gas emitter globally](https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions?breakBy=sector&chartType=area&sectors=agriculture%2Cindustrial-processes%2Cland-use-change-and-forestry%2Cwaste%2Cbuilding%2Celectricity-heat%2Cfugitive-emissions%2Cmanufacturing-construction%2Cother-fuel-combustion%2Ctransportation)* , but the share in national emissions vary. See below how *[Climate Watch](https://www.climatewatchdata.org)* data on *[power sector emissions](https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ghg-emissions)* , proposed *[climate targets in their national cliamte committments (NDCs)](https://www.climatewatchdata.org/ndcs-content)* , and what *[models tell us about future pathways](https://www.climatewatchdata.org/pathways)*.
